A sequence $(a_1,b_1)$, $(a_2,b_2)$, $(a_3,b_3)$, $\ldots$ of points in the coordinate plane satisfies
\[(a_{n + 1}, b_{n + 1}) = (\sqrt {3}a_n - b_n, \sqrt {3}b_n + a_n)\]for $n = 1,2,3,\ldots$.  Suppose that $(a_{100},b_{100}) = (2,4)$. What is $a_1 + b_1$?  Express your answer using exponential notation.
inference:
We can write the given recurrence in matrix form:
\[\begin{pmatrix} a_{n + 1} \\ b_{n + 1} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \sqrt{3} & -1 \\ 1 & \sqrt{3} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} a_n \\ b_n \end{pmatrix}.\]Let
\[M = \begin{pmatrix} \sqrt{3} & -1 \\ 1 & \sqrt{3} \end{pmatrix}.\]Then
\[\begin{pmatrix} a_{100} \\ b_{100} \end{pmatrix} = M^{99} \begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\ b_1 \end{pmatrix}.\]To find $M^{99},$ we can diagonalize $M.$  The characteristic polynomial of $M$ is
\[(x - \sqrt{3})^2 + 1 = x^2 - 2 \sqrt{3} x + 4,\]so the eigenvalues are
\[x = \sqrt{3} \pm i.\]The corresponding eigenvectors are
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ i \end{pmatrix}\]and
\[\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -i \end{pmatrix},\]respectively.  Hence,
\[M = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ i & -i \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} \sqrt{3} + i & 0 \\ 0 & \sqrt{3} - i \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ i & -i \end{pmatrix}^{-1}.\]Then
\begin{align*}
M^{99} &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ i & -i \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} (\sqrt{3} + i)^{99} & 0 \\ 0 & (\sqrt{3} - i)^{99} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ i & -i \end{pmatrix}^{-1} \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ i & -i \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} (\sqrt{3} + i)^{99} & 0 \\ 0 & (\sqrt{3} - i)^{99} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & -i \\ 1 & i \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \begin{pmatrix} (\sqrt{3} + i)^{99} + (\sqrt{3} - i)^{99} & -i (\sqrt{3} + i)^{99} + i (\sqrt{3} - i)^{99} \\ i (\sqrt{3} + i)^{99} - i (\sqrt{3} - i)^{99} & (\sqrt{3} + i)^{99} + (\sqrt{3} - i)^{99} \end{pmatrix}.
\end{align*}Let $z = \sqrt{3} + i.$  Then $\overline{z} = \sqrt{3} - i,$ so
\begin{align*}
z^{99} + \overline{z}^{99} &= 2 \operatorname{Re} (z^{99}) \\
&= 2 |z|^{99} \cos 99 \theta,
\end{align*}where $\theta = \arctan \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} = \frac{\pi}{6}.$  Also,
\begin{align*}
-iz^{99} + i \overline{z}^{99} &= 2i \operatorname{Im} (z^{99}) \\
&= 2i |z|^{99} \sin 99 \theta.
\end{align*}Hence,
\[M^{99} = |z|^{99} \begin{pmatrix} \cos 99 \theta & -\sin 99 \theta \\ \sin 99 \theta & \cos 99 \theta \end{pmatrix}.\]Since $|z| = 2,$
\[M^{99} = 2^{99} \begin{pmatrix} \cos 99 \theta & -\sin 99 \theta \\ \sin 99 \theta & \cos 99 \theta \end{pmatrix}.\]Then
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} = 2^{99} \begin{pmatrix} \cos 99 \theta & -\sin 99 \theta \\ \sin 99 \theta & \cos 99 \theta \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\ b_1 \end{pmatrix}.\]Solving, we find
\[\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\ b_1 \end{pmatrix} = 2^{-99} \begin{pmatrix} \cos 99 \theta & \sin 99 \theta \\ -\sin 99 \theta & \cos 99 \theta \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} = 2^{-98} \begin{pmatrix} \cos 99 \theta + 2 \sin 99 \theta \\ -\sin 99 \theta + 2 \cos 99 \theta \end{pmatrix}.\]Therefore,
\[a_1 + b_1 = 2^{-98} (3 \cos 99 \theta + \sin 99 \theta) = \boxed{2^{-98} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{10}}{2}}.\]

Let $z_n = a_n + b_n i.$  Then
\begin{align*}
z_{n + 1} &= (a_n \sqrt{3} - b_n) + (b_n \sqrt{3} + a_n) i \\
&= a_n (\sqrt{3} + i) + b_n (i \sqrt{3} - 1) \\
&= a_n (\sqrt{3} + i) + b_n i (\sqrt{3} + i) \\
&= (\sqrt{3} + i)(a_n + b_n i) \\\
&= (\sqrt{3} + i) z_n.
\end{align*}Hence, $z_{100} = (\sqrt{3} + i)^{99} z_1.$  To evaluate this expression, we write
\[\sqrt{3} + i = 2 \cdot \left( \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} + \frac{1}{2} i \right) = 2 \operatorname{cis} 30^\circ.\]Then
\[(\sqrt{3} + i)^{99} = 2^{99} \operatorname{cis} 2970^\circ = 2^{99} \operatorname{cis} 90^\circ = 2^{99} i.\]Since $z_{100} = 2 + 4i,$
\[z_1 = \frac{2 + 4i}{2^{99} i} = \frac{4 - 2i}{2^{99}} = \frac{2 - i}{2^{98}},\]so
\[a_1 + b_1 = \frac{2}{2^{98}} - \frac{1}{2^{98}} = \boxed{\frac{1}{2^{98}}}.\]
